column1: Meaux (French pronunciation: ​[mo]) is a commune in the Seine-et-Marne department in the Île-de-France region in the metropolitan area of Paris
column2: France. It is 41.1 km (25.5 mi) east-northeast of the center of Paris.

column1: Meaux is a subprefecture (sous-préfecture) of the Seine-et-Marne department. In France a subprefecture is the chef-lieu (the seat or administrative capital) of an arrondissement: Meaux is the subprefecture of the arrondissement of Meaux. It is also the chef-lieu of a smaller administrative division: the canton of Meaux. Finally
column3: Meaux has been the centre and the main town of an agglomeration community
column4: the Communauté d'agglomération du Pays de Meaux.

column3: Meaux is the second largest city in the Seine-et-Marne department after Chelles (53
column7: one of the four subprefectures of the department of Seine-et-Marne

column1: Inhabitants of Meaux are called Meldois. Both names Meaux and Meldois originated with the Meldi
column2: the Latin name of the original Gaulish tribe who occupied this area of the valley of the Marne river. Although during the Roman period the city was called Iantinum by the Romans
column3: the name of the Meldi persisted and was finally kept for naming both the city and its inhabitants.

column1: Historical buildings and monuments in Meaux are mainly located in the old city
column3: still nowadays partially kept thanks to an important segment of the original surrounding wall from the Gallo-Roman period. A meander of the Marne river divides the old city into the North Quarter (called among the Meldois as the Cathedral Quarter) and the South Quarter (known among the locals as the Market Quarter). In the North Quarter there is the Meaux Cathedral

column5: the old seat of the chapter (le vieux chapitre)

column1: Meaux is nowadays mainly known for Brie de Meaux (a variety of Brie cheese) and the local variety of mustard. Following the official administrative French AOC there are two designations of Brie de Meaux: Brie de Meaux fermier ("farm Brie de Meaux"
column2: made out of the milk from the cows of a single unique producer) and Brie de Meaux laitier (laitier
column3: that is from the French lait
column6: a mixture of the milk of different producers). The Moutarde de Meaux ("Meaux Mustard") recipe is since the 18th century a label commercially owned by the Pommery company and is nowadays derived not only in its traditional well known form but also in a variety of new different ingredient combinations: Honey Mustard
column8: Moutarde Royale (that latter including Cognac in its composition) etc.

column1: Several festivals and concerts are celebrated in Meaux
column2: venues for live music like the Music Festival "Musik'elles" (usually at the end of every summer). There's a local public concert band in Meaux: L'Harmonie du Pays de Meaux. It is constituted by three different ensembles
column3: following different ages: Les Minimes (children)
column4: Les Juniors (teenagers) and L'Harmonie de Meaux (adults). The band is also one of the two official music academies of the town. The other one is the conservatory of the city.

column2: every summer for more than 30 years

column4: a show is played by stage actors in the esplanade situated between the cathedral and the episcopal palace: the Spectacle historique ("History show"). The show represents the history of Meaux all along the Middle Ages and the Renaissance
column7: during World War I (the German advance had been halted at Meaux in 1914 during the First Battle of the Marne).

column14: this is the art and history museum of Meaux) and the Musée de la Grande Guerre du pays de Meaux [fr] (the largest World War I Museum in the world).

column1: The Siege of Meaux took place between October 1421 and May 1422
column2: during the Hundred Years' War between England and France. The besiegers were the English
column3: under Henry V. The town's defence was led by the Bastard of Vaurus
column4: notorious for his savagery. The siege commenced on October 6
column6: and mining and bombardment soon brought down the walls. Casualties began to mount in the English army
column8: 7th Baron de Clifford who had been at the siege of Harfleur
column10: and received the surrender of Cherbourg. The English also began to fall sick rather early into the siege
column11: and it is estimated that one sixteenth of the besiegers died from dysentery and smallpox. On 9 March 1422
column13: although the garrison held out. Under continued bombardment
column14: the garrison gave in as well on 10 March
column15: following a siege of six months. The Bastard of Vaurus was decapitated
column16: as was a trumpeter named Orace
column17: who had once mocked King Henry. Sir John Fortescue was then installed as English Captain of Meaux Castle.

column1: === World War I: First Battle of the Marne ===
During the First Battle of the Marne (September 1914)
column2: the German troops were stopped at the gates of Meaux. This heroic action not only prevented the city from being taken by the Germans but also changed the course of the war. In 1932
column3: at the place of the battlefield
column4: the people of the United States of America had a monument erected in the memory of the French soldiers fallen in action. Called
column7: the sculpture by Frederick MacMonnies is popularly known among the French as Le Monument américain ("the American monument"). Coordinates: 48.973°N 2.905°E﻿ / 48.973; 2.905

column2: beside the monument was built the Museum of the Great War (Musée de la Grande Guerre du pays de Meaux [fr]).

column1: Meaux is served by Meaux station on the Transilien Paris – Est suburban rail line and on several national rail lines. The rail line connecting Paris to Meaux was established in 1849. The nowadays SNCF train station
column3: was built in 1890.Alongside the Meaux rail station there is also the main bus station in the city
column4: with more than 30 bus lines serving the whole eastern Paris metropolitan area.
